name: Eyelash Viper
description: Named for the spiny protrusions above its eyes that disrupt the smooth outline of its large, triangular head. Even more striking is the wide range of colors individuals within a single population can exhibit. These—green, pink, or yellow patches—make it nearly invisible among bush branches, mimicking leaves, lichens, or plant flowers.
spread_note: From southern Mexico to Ecuador and Peru
food_note: Rodents, bats, small lizards, frogs, occasionally birds
image_alt: Eyelash viper, photo: Prague Zoo archive
proportions: Length usually up to 60 cm (rarely over 80 cm); weight up to 220 g
reproduction: Ovoviviparous—young hatch as the female lays eggs.
attractions: It inhabits trees and bushes, often low to the ground, always near water, where it ambushes passing prey. Venomous, its bite is rarely fatal to humans. Females are ovoviviparous, with young hatching as eggs are laid.
breeding: From 1971–1973, we kept three wild-caught individuals. New eyelash vipers arrived at the zoo in 2011.
